close_symbols: struct DigestAlgorithm (full definition including members: algo, uninitialised, algo_selected, ready_for_hashing, hashing, and the ctx union/struct with md5_ctx, sha256_ctx, sha512_256_ctx)
enum MHD_DigestBaseAlgo and its constants (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5, MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256, MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256, MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_INVALID)
MHD_MD5_init_one_time (or the exact MHD_MD5_init implementation called)
MHD_SHA256_init_one_time (or the exact MHD_SHA256_init implementation called)
Definitions/types of the context objects stored in da->ctx (the concrete types of ctx.md5_ctx, ctx.sha256_ctx, ctx.sha512_256_ctx)
All functions called (transitively) by the three init functions above (any helpers those init functions call)
explanation:
- struct DigestAlgorithm: required to know the sizes and layout of the object whose members are written and whose ctx members are passed to the init functions. To judge whether any string.h call writes/reads beyond the bounds we must know the actual object sizes and field offsets.
- enum MHD_DigestBaseAlgo and its constants: required to confirm which branch is taken and whether an init for a particular ctx member is invoked.
- MHD_MD5_init_one_time / MHD_MD5_init implementation: digest_init_one_time delegates initialization to this function. To check MISRA/string.h violations we must inspect its body for calls to memcpy/memset/strcpy/etc and verify the pointer/size arguments are within bounds.
- MHD_SHA256_init_one_time / MHD_SHA256_init implementation: same reason as MD5 init — those implementations may call string.h functions that could access beyond the provided ctx object.
- MHD_SHA512_256_init implementation: same as above for the SHA512_256 path.
- Definitions/types of ctx.md5_ctx, ctx.sha256_ctx, ctx.sha512_256_ctx: the init functions receive pointers to these objects — we need their concrete types and sizes to check that any buffer operations in the init functions are safe for the object passed.
- All functions called (transitively) by the three init functions: if the init implementations call helper functions which themselves use memcpy/memset/strlen/etc, those must be inspected too. Include their implementations to perform a complete bounds-safety analysis.
